bat thesis Kaushik Narasimhan 2019-12-18 1 Questions and Objectives Chapter 1) What is the effect of different levels of historical disturbance on bat species diversity and abundance, community composition? H0: There is no difference in bat species diversity and abundance between forest types summary table - in progress Diversity – Using simpson Estimated richness – accumulation curves raw sp rich raw abundance mixed models on those Whittaker plots NMDS What is the effect of different forest types on vertical stratification of bats in the middle canopy? H0: Net height has no effect on the diversity and abundance of bats captured. - similar to 1) stratified by strata What environmental factors most account for differences in bat species diversity and abundance between forest types? Moon phase, temperature, conopy cover, cloud cover Mixed models e.g. raw richness ~ Moon phase + canopy cover + habitat type + Effort + 1|site H0: The is no difference in effect of environmental factors on bat species d and a Do bats captured in different forest types vary morphologically (don’t know if that is the right word to use. Maybe characters instead?) H0: Bats do not vary morphologically between forest types Response term : forearm length, ear, mass, condition (function mass vs. size) Checkout peig and green’s scaled mass index. Explanatory variables: Forest type Does bat diversity captured via detector differ from bat diversity captured via nets between forest types? H0: Diversity does not differ in forest types from different capture methods.

2 Descriptive Statistics 2.1 Summary Table - A work in progress 2.2 Species Breakdown 2.3 Captures and Richness by forest type 2.4 Captures and Species by site 2.5 Capture by time 2.6 Species Accumulation Curves 2.7 Rarefaction using Vegan 2.8 Deriving Simpson’s Diversity Index 2.9 Lets make a Whittaker plot

3 Chapter 1 3.1 Hypothesis 1: There is no difference in bat species diversity, abundance, richness between forest types 3.2 Hypothesis 2: There is no difference in number of feeding guilds between forest type 3.3 Hypothesis 3: There is no relationship between Abundances of Individual species and forest type

[1] 1.2 ## [1] 1.3 ## [1] 0.3 ## Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variance (center = median) ## Df F value Pr(>F) ## group 2 0.3333 0.723 ## 12 ## ## Shapiro-Wilk normality test ## ## data: b1$Feeding.Guild ## W = 0.88103, p-value = 0.04916 ## ## Shapiro-Wilk normality test ## ## data: b1[b1$Forest.Type == "CCR", ]$Feeding.Guild ## W = 0.82827, p-value = 0.135 ## ## Shapiro-Wilk normality test ## ## data: b1[b1$Forest.Type == "PCR", ]$Feeding.Guild ## W = 0.95873, p-value = 0.6703 While the variances are homogenous, feeding guild fails the shapiro-wilkes test. The QQ plot seems borderline, I will assume that this is non-parametric and use a kruskal-wallis test. 3.2.1.3 Results term estimate std.error statistic p.value (Intercept) 4.8 0.4320494 11.1098412 1.13582774040274e-07 Forest.TypePCR -1.4 0.6110101 -2.2912878 0.0408362971052916 Forest.TypeSLR -0.2 0.6110101 -0.3273268 0.749060275187656 r.squared adj.r.squared sigma statistic p.value df deviance df.residual 0.3385827 0.2283465 0.9660918 3.071429 0.0837246596259315 3 11.2 12 Not significant, p-value is .10 Ok, feeding guild itself is not significant, but what if we look at individual feeding guilds? High flying frugivores and low flying frugivores are both strongly represented. Lets test each one against forest type. 3.2.2 High flying frugivores ~ Forest Type 3.2.2.1 Boxplots SLR seems like it is different… 3.2.2.2 assumptions ## [1] 42.3 ## [1] 49.7 ## [1] 66 ## Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variance (center = median) ## Df F value Pr(>F) ## group 2 0.0407 0.9603 ## 12 ## ## Shapiro-Wilk normality test ## ## data: b1$HFF ## W = 0.8997, p-value = 0.09417 ## ## Shapiro-Wilk normality test ## ## data: b1[b1$Forest.Type == "CCR", ]$HFF ## W = 0.8034, p-value = 0.08634 ## ## Shapiro-Wilk normality test ## ## data: b1[b1$Forest.Type == "PCR", ]$HFF ## W = 0.75661, p-value = 0.03423 ## ## Shapiro-Wilk normality test ## ## data: b1[b1$Forest.Type == "SLR", ]$HFF ## W = 0.92034, p-value = 0.5321 ## ## Shapiro-Wilk normality test ## ## data: aov.hff.resid ## W = 0.93866, p-value = 0.3658 Assumptions are met. 3.2.2.3 Results term estimate std.error statistic p.value (Intercept) 7.6 3.245510 2.3416969 0.0372706091610285 Forest.TypePCR 3.2 4.589844 0.6971915 0.498967896491153 Forest.TypeSLR 8.4 4.589844 1.8301276 0.0921674262778643 r.squared adj.r.squared sigma statistic p.value df deviance df.residual 0.2214192 0.0916557 7.25718 1.706329 0.222752295120196 3 632 12 Not significant, p-value=0.223. 4 Chapter 2 4.1 Hypothesis 4: No difference in abundance, richness, and diversity by height as a result of forest type 4.2 Hypothesis 5: No difference between feeding guilds between net heights at forest types 4.3 Hypothesis 6: No difference between feeding guilds between net heights at different forest types

4 Chapter 2 4.1 Hypothesis 4: No difference in abundance, richness, and diversity by height as a result of forest type 4.1.1 Abundance, Richness of net height ~ Forest Type My nets were subdivided
